question: What are you looking for in your next role?
answer: First and foremost, I'm looking for a role that allows me to continue to grow and learn. I'm open to new challenges and opportunities to lead and mentor others. I'm also looking for a role that allows me to continue to work on interesting technical problems and to be part of a team that is passionate about what they do. I want to work with awesome people and develop awesome products that make a difference.

question: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
answer: Designing, developing and fine tuning embodied AI, specifically advanced knowledge and memory systems.

question: Why are you open to new opportunities right now?
answer: I'm not actively looking but I'm open to new opportunities if the right one comes along.

question: What is your greatest strength?
answer: I'll give you two: 1) leadership and mentorship and 2) being able to take a complex problem and break it down into smaller, more manageable parts.

question: What sets you apart from other candidates?
answer: Objectively speaking, I'm not the most technically skilled candidate in the room. However, I'm the most technically curious candidate in the room. I'm a retired Army officer that's working on a doctorate, with multiple post-graduate certificates and sixteen professional and technical certifications.

question: Describe your leadership style.
answer: I'm a servant leader. I love to help people grow and develop their skills. I'm a big believer in servant leadership and that the best way to lead is to help others reach their full potential.

question: How do you handle conflict on your team?
answer: Communication. I also think that being able to take a step back and look at the big picture is important. I also recognize that if I'm responsible for a decision, I need to be able to own it and take responsibility for it.

question: Tell me about a time you had to make a difficult decision.
answer: When modernizing the BLCSE OneSAF system, I had to make the decision to move from a legacy system to a modern system. I had to make the decision to move, force the move to Kubernetes and Docker against the opinion of my engineering team.

question: How do you stay current with emerging technologies?
answer: School. I read a lot - books, articles, papers. I have lots of discussions with AI. I'm always asking questions and seeking answers.

question: What's your approach to evaluating new AI/ML technologies for enterprise use?
answer: I'll keep this short: what's the business problem? What's the technical problem? What data is on-hand?

question: How do you balance innovation with security in classified environments?
answer: Understanding what risk really is, the probability of the risk occurring, the impact of the risk, and the controls in place to mitigate the risk. I think it's important to design security into the system from the beginning.

question: Tell me about a challenging project you've worked on.
answer: I'm working on a system project that includes hardware, software, and network components. It's a complex system that includes a lot of different technologies and disciplines. A large chunk of the software is an AI-enabled architecture that includes Kalman filters, a feedforward neural network but also requiring a deep understanding of the sensor technologies and their message formats.

question: Describe a project where you had to recover a failing program.
answer: When modernizing the BLCSE OneSAF system, I had to recover a failing program. I had to make the decision to force radical change, beginning with a focus on government deliverables. Once that foundation was set I had to force modernization in an organization that had essentially remained unchanged for two decades.

question: What's the most innovative solution you've architected?
answer: I think the STE was the most innovative because it was the most disruptive change to the way the Army does business. It was a complete transformation of the way the Army delivers collective training.

question: What kind of company culture do you thrive in?
answer: I like casual, professional. I also think it's important to be supportive of each other. Leadership is important. Teamwork is important. We're all in this together.

question: How do you approach mentoring junior engineers?
answer: It's a relationship thing. You have to start with trust, respect and understand that their goals are not my goals.

question: What's been the biggest challenge in your career?
answer: Understanding how to navigate the political landscape of the Army and the Joint Staff and how to influence decisions and recognizing different incentives and motivations.

question: Tell me about a time you failed and what you learned.
answer: On the Joint Staff I had to ship over one-hundred laptops to Germany overnight. I was counting on two cybersecurity personnel, one in the Joint Staff and another in Germany to get work done. They didn't so I had to ship the laptops. I was responsible to the problem and cost was mine; but, because I was ignorant I didn't realize it wasn't likely that they'd get the work done nor could I explain the issue to my senior executive leadership. So I learned that I can no longer be technically ignorant. That's when I started learning tech.

question: What motivates you professionally?
answer: Learning and growing. A good, supportive team environment. A role that allows me to make a difference.

question: Why did you transition from military to private sector?
answer: I retired. If I had stayed in, I would have been a Colonel by now. But that would have meant another PCS move, a year away from my family to attend the War College and likely another year away on a deployment. And truthfully, none of the Colonel positions interested me. I would have really locked myself into the Army for another eight years, trading prestige - the rank - for professioanl growth.
